description:
Alchemy tore the Elric brothers’ bodies apart. Can their bond make them whole again?
In this world, alchemists are those who study and perform the art of alchemical transmutation—the science of manipulating and transforming matter. They are bounded by the Law of Equivalent Exchange: in order to gain something, one must sacrifice something of equal value.
In an alchemical ritual gone wrong, Edward Elric lost his arm and his leg, and his brother Alphonse became nothing but a soul in a suit of armor. Equipped with mechanical “auto-mail” limbs, Edward becomes a state alchemist, seeking the one thing that can restore his and his brother’s bodies...the legendary Philosopher’s Stone.

(Source: Viz Media)

Note: Includes 8 extra chapters.
synonyms: แขนกลคนแปรธาตุ

tags.name: Alchemy
tags.description: Features character(s) who practice alchemy.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Disability
tags.description: A work that features one or more characters with a physical, mental, cognitive, or developmental condition that impairs, interferes with, or limits the person's ability to engage in certain tasks or actions.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Chimera
tags.description: Features a beast made by combining animals, usually with humans.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Shapeshifting
tags.description: Features character(s) who changes one's appearance or form.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: Cars
tags.description: Centers around the use of automotive vehicles.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Trains
tags.description: Prominently features trains.

node.description:
Her self-portrait is usually that of a bespectacled cow, as she was born and raised in a dairy farm with three older sisters and a younger brother. Arakawa started out as [Etou Hiroyuki's](https://anilist.co/staff/98901/) assistant writer for [Mahoujin Guru Guru](https://anilist.co/manga/34080/) and a friend of [Shakugan no Shana](https://anilist.co/manga/33074/) author [Yashichiro Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99114/). Arakawa's career started with a work titled [STRAY DOG](https://anilist.co/manga/33303/), but she is best known for creating the [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/manga/30025/) world and manga. The author is friends with [Akira Segami](https://anilist.co/staff/97387/).

Due to a lack of real publicity photos of Arakawa, a great sum of her fanbase has no idea what she really looks like, even to this day. There are some scarce pictures of the real Arakawa in the web, but they are very low in quality and are rarely used as reference. Many fans have mistaken photos of [Romi Park](https://anilist.co/staff/95082/Romi-Park), Edward Elric's seiyuu, as photos of Arakawa, because of the set-up in one particular image in which Romi Park poses as a mangaka. Romi Park is known for representing Arakawa in public appearances, in which Arakawa is not able to attend. 

_Awards:_
• 1999: 9th 21st Century Enix Award for "Stray Dog"
• 2003: 49th Shogakukan Manga Award, Shōnen category for "Fullmetal Alchemist"
• 2011: 15th Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize, "New Artist Prize" category.
• 2011: 42nd Seiun Award, "Best Science Fiction Comic" category for "Fullmetal Alchemist"
• 2012: 5th Manga Taishō Award for "Silver Spoon"
• 2012: 58th Shogakukan Manga Award, Shōnen category for "Silver Spoon"
• 2013: 1st Contents Award of Japan Food Culture Grand Prize for "Silver Spoon"
• 2023: 1st Rakuten Kobo's E-Book Manga Award, "I Want to Read it Now! Featured Manga" category for "Yomi no Tsugai"
• 2023: 7th Tsutaya Comic Award for "Yomi no Tsugai"
Annette Nordheim is a Norwegian store manager and translator.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/pawel_dybala)
Besides translation, he also does lectures and research at the Jagiellonian University in Kraków. Works with publishers J.P.Fantastica and Egmont Poland.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/namazudou)

__Birth place:__ Ota, Tokyo

Takaeda is a former assistant of the mangaka [Hiromu Arakawa](https://anilist.co/staff/96874/Hiromu-Arakawa)

She is the creator of the Splatoon manga who worked on Kanitama-Kun, Arincho-Kun, Mega Man, and The Dempa Men before being attached to the Splatoon characters so much that she had to work on the Splatoon manga more. 

She was an assistant of the famous mangaka [Akiko Higashimura](https://anilist.co/staff/99186/Akiko-Higashimura) and [Hiromu Arakawa](https://anilist.co/staff/96874/Hiromu-Arakawa).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hinodeya3) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/10470871)

When *Dragon Ball* started to be published in Swedish in 2000 as the trailblazer for the Swedish '00s manga boom, Lundström – who had many years prior co-founded Mangakai, Sweden's at the time largest (and nowadays oldest still existing) Japanese pop culture society – was instrumental in facilitating the project business-wise. 

He went on to be one of Sweden's most prolific manga translators, until he was arrested in 2009 and the publisher with whom he worked transferred his titles to other translators. 

Although he was acquitted on all counts, by the time the legal dispute was over in 2012, the Swedish manga industry had collapsed, and – bar volume 66 of One Piece, the last one ever published in Swedish – there was no work to return to. In 2021, he returned to the manga sphere for the first time in almost a decade, to translate Nosebleed Studio's first licensed manga, *Vampires vs. Zombies*.
